definitions.definition: to give somebody something that they can use, or some work or responsibility

examples.text: The teacher assigned a different task to each of the children.
The two large classrooms have been assigned to us.
We have been assigned the two large classrooms.
The teacher assigned each of the children a different task.

definitions.definition: to provide a person for a particular task or position
definitions.sensetop: assign somebody (to something/as something)assign somebody to do something

examples.text: They've assigned their best man to the job.
Two senior officers have been assigned to the case.
British forces have been assigned to help with peacekeeping.

definitions.definition: to send a person to work under the authority of somebody or in a particular group

examples.text: I was assigned to B platoon.
He was assigned to the Royal Canadian Navy in 1975.

definitions.definition: to say that something has a particular value or function, or happens at a particular time or place
definitions.sensetop: assign something to somethingassign something sth

examples.text: Assign a different colour to each different type of information.
The painting cannot be assigned an exact date.

definitions.definition: to say that your property or rights now belong to somebody else

examples.text: The agreement assigns copyright to the publisher.
She has assigned the lease to her daughter.

definitions.definition: to be said to have a particular gender when you are born

examples.text: They were assigned male at birth but identify as female.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French asigner, assiner, from Latin assignare, from ad- ‘to’ + signare ‘to sign’.
